seg.line: 秦穆公師百里奚、公孫枝，

tls:text.tls:srcline: 秦穆公師百里奚、公孫枝，

form.pron: bǎi bó mò bǎi lǐ xī

sense.def: 伯里子 (7th century) from the state of Chu, mostly referred to as Bo Lixi 百里奚 or as Bo Lizi 百里子, was a cowherd from the tiny state of Yu 虞, and according to HSWZ 8.25 even a beggar, who was taken prisoner when >Duke Xian of Jin 晉獻公 (r. 676-651) destroyed that small state of Yu in 655. Bo Lizi was repeatedly resold (百里奚轉鬻), as HNZ 19.3b puts it memorably. SJ 83.2743 reports that he was a beggar until he was brought into politics by Duke Mu of Qin 秦穆公 (r. 659 - 621). He sold himself for for five sheep-skins to Duke Mu of Qin according to HSWZ 7.6. SJ 39.1653 has him in conversation with Duke Mu of Qin. A remarkable case of social mobility in ancient China, he became a reform-minded prime minister who helped that duke dominate the neighbouring states. [HNZ 10.11b] He is often mentioned on a par with >Guan Zhong 管仲 (d. 643) who played a similar role in the service of >Duke Huan of Qi 齊桓公.

Bào Shūyá 鮑叔牙 (fl. 686-685), also referred to as Bao Shu 鮑叔was an admirer and a friend [HNZ 12.28a] of >Guan Zhong 管仲, and he made the selfless recommendation in Guan Zhong’s favour to the newly appointed >Duke Huan of Qi 齊桓公. Guan Zhong was deeply grateful to him. Bào Shūyá figures prominently as a selflessly competent adviser in GUAN and elsewhere in the literature. HNZ 20.25b records his important contribution to the rise of Duke Huan to political hegemony. [ZUO Zhuang 8 and 9; Zhao 13; XUN 21; GUAN passim.]
Bó(Báo) Yí 薄疑 (fl. c. 300) served as an official in the state of Zhao 趙 and and also to >Lord Si of Wey 衛嗣君. [LSCQ 13.6; 13.7, 18.1, 26.2; HNZ 12.7a; ZGC Song, and ZGC Wei]

Biàn Suí 卞隨 (late Xia dynasty), along with >Wu Guan 務光, was said to have been a recluse of the end of the Xia dynasty. [SJ 61.2121] Bian Sui is said to have refused to accept the offer to become the ruler of the new Shang dynasty and to have drowned himself in the River Ying 潁 to escape the attentions of the Xia leadership. [LSCQ 19.1; ZHUANG 28; XUN 25.309; HSWZ 1.25; ZGC Qin 5]

Bó Lè 伯樂 (1) (7th century), whose real name was Sūn Yáng 孫陽, was an exemplary horse specialist in ancient China. [XUN 12.159; HNZ 2.9a, 9.22b, 11.13b] He is reported to have been a minister at the court of of Duke Mù of Qín 秦穆公 (r. 659 - 621). [HNZ 12.12b] But the context of his story in HF would actually place Bo Le around 500. Thus HF is taken to refer to another Bo Le (2) (fl. 500), also a specialist in the adjudication of horses, who was a driver for >Zhao Jianzi 趙簡子 (fl. 517-475). Stories about Bó Lè abound throughout Warring States literature, and it often remains unclear which of the two is being referred to. His name has tended to become a generic designation for specialists in the adjudication of horses, and indeed for professional specialists. LSCQ 9.5 commends Bo Le for his complete specialisation and concentration on horsemanship. [HSWZ 7.6; CC 8; ZHUANG 9; LSCQ 25.4]

Cāngjié 蒼頡/倉頡 (legendary) was regarded as the inventor of writing in China. SHIBEN claims he was a senior minister under the legendary >Yellow Emperor himself. He is said to have been endowed with four eyes and supreme wisdom. The traditions concerning him are judiciously presented in F. Bottéro, “Cang Jie and the invention of writing. Reflections on the elaboration of a legend”, in Halvor Eifring and Christoph Anderl, eds., Festschrift Christoph Harbsmeier, p. 135-155.

seg.line: 乃使長魚矯殺郄犨、郄錡、郄至于朝而陳其尸。

tls:text.tls:srcline: 乃使長魚矯殺郄犨、郄錡、郄至于朝而陳其尸。

sense.def: Cháng Yújiăo 長魚矯 (died 573) was a sycophantic confidant of >Duke Li of Jin 晉厲公 (r. 580 – 573). According to LSCQ 20.7 Duke Li ordered him to kill a number of political enemies and to expose their bodies to public view in the court. [GY Jin 6; GY Chu 2.18] Chang Yujiao was himself murdered along with his master in 573. [ZUO Cheng 17, SHANGBO 姑成家父]

Chìyóu 蚩尤 was said to be a descendant of >Emperor Yan of the Shang 商炎帝 . His surname was Jiang 姜. He counted as the most luan 亂 “unruly” of the nobles of his time. On the other hand he is said to have been the first to have used metal in order to produce weapons. [GUAN 77] A mythical warrior, originally also said to have been a supporter of the Yellow Emperor, he nonetheless defeated and killed by the Yellow Emperor in the battle of Zhuo Lu 涿鹿. [SJ 1.4 etc.] A military classic is attributed to him in the bibliography of HS, but this has long been lost. According to the old commentary to the LSCQ 7.1, Chiyou was legendary leader of the 九黎 “Nine Tribes” of the East. LSCQ 7.2 explicitly rejects reports that he was the inventor of metal weaponry 人曰「蚩尤作兵」，蚩尤非作兵也. [SHU 25; SJ 1.3ff, and 28; ZHUANG 29; DDLJ 33] See Birrell, Mythology p. 296

Marquis Hŭ of Chóng 崇侯虎 (11th century) was a trusted senior minister under Emperor Xin 帝辛, the King Zhou of Shang 商紂王. When the Earl Chang of the West 西伯昌 (future >King Wen of Zhou 周文王) showed his disapproval of the of Emperor Xin 帝辛 in the Marquis of Chong’s presence, the latter reports this loyally to Emperor Xin and warns against the future the Earl of the West. The Earl is imprisoned in Youli 羑里 (ZSJN 231). When the Earl of the West was liberated, he launched a punitive attack against Marquis Chong 崇侯. [LSCQ 2.4; SY 15.17 and 17.2; JINLOUZI 興王篇]

Dōngguō Yá 東郭牙 (seventh cent.) was a contemporary of >Duke Huan of Qi 齊桓公. He is described as an aide and an able remonstrator in HF 33. He is listed together with >Xi Peng 隰朋, >Xian Ning 弦甯, >Ning Ji 甯疾, >Prince Cheng-fu 王子成甫, and the famous >Guan Zhong 管仲 (d. 643) as an able political adviser. [GUAN 56 and 20.11; SY 1.17; HSWZ 4.5; XINXU 4] [HF 33.12; 33.28]

Fù Yuè 傅說 (11th cent.) is said to have been a corvee slave during the reign of >King Wuding 商王武丁(c. 1238-1179). [SY 11.10] His humble origins are commonly referred to in the literature. He was appointed prime minister to King Wuding as a result of the King having a dream about him. [MENG 6B15; XUN 5.47; HSWZ 7.6; SY 17.18; SJ 2].

Gōngsūn Hóng 公孫弘 [fl. ca. 300] from Wei 魏 is said to be a man from Qi 齊 in the commentary to ZGC Qi 4.2. He is quoted extensively in conversation with >Lord Mengchang 孟嘗君 (d. 279) also in LSCQ 12.5. He must not be confused with the famous Han dynasty politician of the same name. [LSCQ 12.3; ZGC Qi 4.1] HF 23

Gōng Zhīqí 宮之奇 (fl. 658). A courtier in the small state of Yú 虞, whose advice to appease the much larger state of Jin 晉 and allow them right of way through Yu territory went unheeded in a famous episode. The result was the destruction of the state of Yú 虞 at the hands of neighbouring much larger state of Jin 晉.This famous episode occurred in 658 and is reported in lively detail in ZUO Xi 5. [MENG 5A9; GULIANG Xi 4; XUN 32; LSCQ 15.4, 22.5, ZGC passim]

Gōngzĭ Jiū 公子糾 (d. 685) was was a brother and rival of >Duke Huan of Qi 齊桓公. >Guan Zhong 管仲 (d. 643) served originally as an advisor to Prince Jiu. In 685 Duke Huan defeated Prince Jiu, who fled to the state of Lu where he was killed by the ruler of Lu. (LY14.16 and14.17 describe this as Prince Jiu being murdered by his brother Duke Huan. The story is told in some detail in GUAN 18 and GUAN 20. [ZUO Zhuang 8; LSCQ 15.6]

King Gōu Jiàn of Yue 越王勾踐（句踐) (r. 497 – 465) inherited the throne from King Yunchang of Yue 越王允常. After losing a major battle against King Fuchai of Wu 武王夫差 in 494 he served for three years as a human hostage in the state of Wu. After his return to Yue he collaborated with >Wen Zhong 文種 and >Fan Li 范蠡 in the strengthening of his state. In 482 he availed himself of the absence of King Fuchai on a diplomatic mission, invaded the state of Wu and captured the heir apparent of Wu, Crown Prince You 太子友. After several further attacks he finally destroyed the state of Wu in 473. [ZUO Ai 22] Thus strengthened he established a vertical alliance with Qi and Jin of which he became the recognised ba 霸 “hegemon”. One of the hegemons [ba] of the Warring States period, this king of Yue is famous throughout the literature for his wars with the neighbouring state of Wu 吳. GY Yueyu is entirely devoted to Gou Jian. A lively narrative of his life will be found in SJ 31, and an elaborate fictional version is in WUYUECHUNQIU. Rich archeological evidence on Gou Jian has been unearthed during the last decades. [LSCQ 19.4; HNZ 11; HSWZ 7.13 et passim; ZGC passim].

seg.line: 關龍逢、王子比干能以要領之死，

tls:text.tls:srcline: 關龍逢、王子比干能以要領之死，

sense.def: Guān Lóngpáng 關龍逢 (legendary; Xia). A minister to King Jie 桀王, the (legendary) wicked last emperor of the Xia dynasty, who remonstrated against the emperor's excesses and was executed for his recalcitrance is commonly mentioned throughout ancient literature. [ZHUANG 4] [LSCQ 2.5; XUN 21.259, 28.345; HSWZ 1.26, 4.2, 7.6]

seg.line: 猶尚有管叔、蔡叔之事與東夷八國不聽之謀。

tls:text.tls:srcline: 猶尚有管叔、蔡叔之事與東夷八國不聽之謀。

sense.def: Guăn Shū 管叔 (11th century), often referred to more speciafically as 管叔鮮 was a younger brother of >King Wu of Zhou and son of >King Wen of Zhou. After the victory of King Wu of Zhou over the Shang Guan Shu was enfeoffed in Guan 管 to oversee the survivors of the Shang 商. But when King Wu died and >King Cheng of Zhou 周成王 (r. 1042-1020) ascended the throne as a minor, Guan Shu and his brother >Cai Shudu 蔡叔度 conspired with the sons of the last Shang emperor Zhòu 紂 against King Wu’s heir, King Cheng of Zhou, who was then a child. They were suppressed by another of their brothers, Duke Dan of Zhou 周公旦, commonly referred to simply as the >Duke of Zhou 周公 who acted as guardian to the then still minor King Cheng of Zhou. [Passim]

tls:text.tls:srcline: 人不愛崑山之玉、江漢之珠，

tls:text.tls:srcline: 至聖變習移俗而莫知其所從，

sense.def: e.g. 所聞於相國 "what (I) have heard from the prime minister of state" direct object of a ditransitive verbal construction

sense.def: direct object: e.g. 所樂 "what (the understood/contextually determinate subject) enjoys": that which (the understood subject) Vt-s； the object Vt-ed by the the understood subject

tls:text.tls:line: using the present to know the past,

accept (and, in case of an order, obey);

tls:text.tls:line: he encountered bandits on the Ousha.

tls:text.tls:line: The bandits demanded what he was carrying in his sack,

sense.def: make demands for

tls:text.tls:line: As a general principle,

sense.def: quite generally; as a matter of principle, speaking in general of (the topic);

tls:text.tls:line: Thus, as general rule, it is necessary for men to eliminate such partiality before they can know a thing completely.

sense.def: quite generally; very generally speaking; as a matter of principle, speaking in general of (the topic);

tls:text.tls:line: As a generel rule, attacks and chastisements,

sense.def: quite generally, speaking of S1, S2

tls:text.tls:line: As a gneral principle, other men too must study their own hearts,

sense.def: quite generally; very generally speaking; as a matter of principle, speaking in general of (the topic);

tls:text.tls:line: would the Master condemn the King?"

sense.def: should; must

tls:text.tls:line: And so an expert in producing echoes does not concentrate on the echo, but on the sound,

sense.def: excel in the use of N, be competent in the matter of N; be an expert in the matter of N

tls:text.tls:line: "He who obtains the Dao of Heaven becomes a Sovereign;

sense.def: Sovereign; Thearch

tls:text.tls:line: he who obtains the Dao of Earth becomes one of the Three Dukes.

sense.def: Threefold Lord; a senior Lord, an honorary official with moral duties. ranking above the feudal lords and right next to the Emperor

tls:text.tls:line: and they were based on the Great One.太一

sense.def: =大一 Grand Primordial Unison

tls:text.tls:line: and they were based on the Great One.太一

sense.def: =大一, =天一 Grand Primordial Unison，成玄英疏：“大一，天也。” 亦指北极神。

tls:text.tls:line: The great one generated the two Forces

sense.def: =大一 Grand Primordial Unison

tls:text.tls:line: The great one generated the two Forces

sense.def: =大一, =天一 Grand Primordial Unison，成玄英疏：“大一，天也。” 亦指北极神。

tls:text.tls:line: The great one generated the two Forces

sense.def: the two, the dyad of; the pair of

tls:text.tls:line: they have been created by the Great One

sense.def: =大一 Grand Primordial Unison

tls:text.tls:line: they have been created by the Great One

sense.def: =大一, =天一 Grand Primordial Unison，成玄英疏：“大一，天也。” 亦指北极神。

tls:text.tls:line: but if under pressure one does this, one calls it the Great One.

sense.def: =大一 Grand Primordial Unison

tls:text.tls:line: but if under pressure one does this, one calls it the Great One.

sense.def: =大一, =天一 Grand Primordial Unison，成玄英疏：“大一，天也。” 亦指北极神。

tls:text.tls:line: His spirit is conjoined with the Grand One, //

sense.def: =大一 Grand Primordial Unison

tls:text.tls:line: His spirit is conjoined with the Grand One, //

sense.def: =大一, =天一 Grand Primordial Unison，成玄英疏：“大一，天也。” 亦指北极神。

tls:text.tls:line: Understanding the spirit is called attaining to oneness.

sense.def: unitary entity; unit; unison; Unison; undifferentiated oneness, indifferent equivalence;

tls:text.tls:line: Thus when one properly understands oneness

sense.def: unitary entity; unit; unison; Unison; undifferentiated oneness, indifferent equivalence;

tls:text.tls:line: Thus if one knows how to understand unity

sense.def: unitary entity; unit; unison; Unison; undifferentiated oneness, indifferent equivalence;

tls:text.tls:line: As for oneness, one does not want to keep it in one place,

sense.def: unitary entity; unit; unison; Unison; undifferentiated oneness, indifferent equivalence;

tls:text.tls:line: Thus as for the One it organises and gives orders,制令

sense.def: unitary entity; unit; unison; Unison; undifferentiated oneness, indifferent equivalence;

tls:text.tls:line: Thus he who, on the basis of the One, can attend to government,

sense.def: overall unified vision of things; the relevant unifying principle (of the Way as applying to the situation)

tls:text.tls:line: He who is able to govern his own person through the One

sense.def: overall unified vision of things; the relevant unifying principle (of the Way as applying to the situation)

tls:text.tls:line: As for him who is able to govern his own state through the One,

sense.def: overall unified vision of things; the relevant unifying principle (of the Way as applying to the situation)

tls:text.tls:line: If one is capable of governing all under heaven,

sense.def: overall unified vision of things; the relevant unifying principle (of the Way as applying to the situation)

tls:text.tls:line: Because he was a fair and upright man

sense.def: by nature he; as a person

tls:text.tls:line: - [and their desires are the same,] SEE BELOW

sense.def: (in subordinate sentences) he, she, it, they

seg.line: 其所為欲異口惽之命不愉

tls:text.tls:srcline: 其所為欲異口惽之命不愉
tls:text.tls:line: - [what they do in resonse to those desires is different] SEE BELOW

sense.def: (in subordinate sentences) he, she, it, they

tls:text.tls:line: some wield the large posts that ran down the earth at the top of the wall,

sense.def: some (... others)

tls:text.tls:line: and still others carry the surveying instrument in order to inspect things at a great distance expertly.

sense.def: someone else (other than a contextually determinate N); others

tls:text.tls:line: Had Tang and Wu not encountered Jie and Zhou Xin,

sense.def: if, counter to fact

tls:text.tls:line: And when these have not quite begun to be distinguished

sense.def: not ever; never so far

seg.line: 今非徒免於刑戮死辱也

tls:text.tls:srcline: 今非徒免於刑戮死辱也
tls:text.tls:line: Now they have not only avoided physicla punishment and execution, death and humiliation.

sense.def: not only

tls:text.tls:line: It was not merely to accompany his lord,

sense.def: not only

tls:text.tls:line: Tang and Wu were capable, not merely of using their owm people,

sense.def: not only

tls:text.tls:line: The people were made to farm not only so that the earth would yield benefits,

sense.def: not only

tls:text.tls:line: not because of any personal interest in worthies,

sense.def: this is not because

tls:text.tls:line: The establishment of a lord was not done out of partiality for lords,

sense.def: this is not because

tls:text.tls:line: nor the heads of office out of partiality for heads of office.

sense.def: this is not because

tls:text.tls:line: As a general principle, rewards should not be given because the ruler loves persons,

sense.def: this is not because

tls:text.tls:line: is not because they seek profit,

sense.def: not be in order toV(0)

tls:text.tls:line: then your servant will surely die.

sense.def: if not V1 then V2> either V1 or V2

tls:text.tls:line: if not undertaken for the sake of profit, are assuredly for the sake of reputation.

sense.def: if not V1 then V2> either V1 or V2

tls:text.tls:line: It may properly be said of Duke Huan that he "knew how to distribute reward."

sense.def: know how to; know that one must; know that one should

seg.line: 夫有所愛所重而令姦邪盜賊寇亂之人卒必辱之此孝子忠臣親父交友之大事

tls:text.tls:srcline: 夫有所愛所重而令姦邪盜賊寇亂之人卒必辱之此孝子忠臣親父交友之大事
tls:text.tls:line: It is the greatest of calamities for the dead that their filial sons, loyal servants, parents, and friends cause those whom they love and value to be shamed and disgraced by corrupt and wicked men, thieves, hoodlums, and brigands.

sense.def: (be) the most important matter/thing/undertaking/task for/in N

tls:text.tls:line: is the worthiest man in the world.

sense.def: the most V(s) of the Ns in the world

seg.line: 其食足以食天下之賢者

tls:text.tls:srcline: 其食足以食天下之賢者
tls:text.tls:line: has enough food to feed the worthies of the world,

sense.def: the most V(s) of the Ns in the world

seg.line: 其車足以乘天下之賢者

tls:text.tls:srcline: 其車足以乘天下之賢者
tls:text.tls:line: enough chariots to provide transportation for them,

sense.def: the most V(s) of the Ns in the world

seg.line: 其財足以禮天下之賢者

tls:text.tls:srcline: 其財足以禮天下之賢者
tls:text.tls:line: enough material goods to provide courtious gifts for them,

sense.def: the most V(s) of the Ns in the world

tls:text.tls:line: Why should the worthy rulers of the world

sense.def: the most V(s) of the Ns in the world

seg.line: 人子人臣人子之所甚願也

tls:text.tls:srcline: 人子人臣人子之所甚願也
tls:text.tls:line: are what sons and ministers in general very much hope for.

sense.def: hope for (something) 願之， 臣之所甚願

tls:text.tls:line: all wish for a long life, and hope to see the light of day for a long time,

sense.def: hope to; would like to (what you are not sure to be able to achieve)

tls:text.tls:line: they hoped only to be fortunate enough to survive.

sense.def: have high hopes for; hope (often unrealistically) for; have any realistic hope for

seg.line: 欲先生之以此聽寡人也

tls:text.tls:srcline: 欲先生之以此聽寡人也
tls:text.tls:line: This is why I hope that my Master will obey me."

sense.def: hope that S

tls:text.tls:line: and hoped for the defeat of the Qi army.

sense.def: hope that S

tls:text.tls:line: in hopes of encountering the ghost and stabbing it to death.

sense.def: fervently hope to; would dearly like to (what you are not sure to be able to achieve)

tls:text.tls:line: but, because he hoped to rescue the state from its impending disaster,

sense.def: hope to

tls:text.tls:line: Having large forces can be a great blessing,

gramGrp.tls:sem-feat: post V>Nab as SUBJECT of another V>Nab

sense.def: 眾之為福 "the being a good fortune of (one's army) being numerous": modification by one V>Nab specifying the subject of another V>Nab

tls:text.tls:line: then one's responses to all kinds of transformations in things

sense.def: transformation of things
